thread.title: Expedia has long-term plan to greatly expand new campus
thread.title_full: Expedia has long-term plan to greatly expand new campus | The Seattle Times

author: Sanjay Bhatt
title: Expedia has long-term plan to greatly expand new campus
text:
Expedia is working on a long-range master plan to expand development on the travel giant’s new 41-acre waterfront campus to as much as 1.9 million square feet, an official said Thursday.
That would be almost half again as much as the 1.3 million square feet the city had approved for Amgen, the site’s former owner, and nearly three times the total of buildings now on the site.
The Bellevue-based company announced in the spring it had bought the former Amgen campus on the Seattle waterfront for $229 million and planned to move its headquarters by the end of 2018. The company at the time said it plans to have more than 4,500 employees there.
The campus now has six buildings and a parking garage, totaling 670,834 gross square feet and 1,230 parking spaces, Expedia said. In April, Expedia said it planned to build an additional 200,000 square feet of space.
Most Read Stories ESPN video: Percy Harvin opens up about what went wrong in Seattle Amazon angst: from traffic to housing, we’re all worked up It’s election time. Will Howard Schultz run for president? Godden trailing; 5 incumbents move on for City Council Seahawks safety Kam Chancellor still holding out with no end in sight The city had approved Amgen for up to 1.3 million square feet of development on the campus.
Expedia said Thursday through a spokeswoman that it would like the city to raise that limit to either 1.6 million square feet or 1.9 million square feet, with 3,300 parking spaces under both scenarios.
The company said it would retain and expand three of the four existing buildings, a central utility plant and the existing 1,230-space parking garage. The company would add between five and six new buildings, including a new parking garage.
Expedia will begin a master-planning process required by the city for large tracts of land to evaluate its needs through 2030.
The planning process will include looking at the impact of the campus’ growth on the environment and traffic, the company said.
The company said it isn’t seeking to change the current 65-foot height limit on the property, or the 100-foot view corridor at West Prospect Street. It also plans to preserve public access that exists now along the waterfront.
Sanjay Bhatt: 206-464-3103 or sbhatt@seattletimes.com On Twitter @sbhatt
